title: Permanent resident sentenced to 365 days in county jail has immigration hold, can anythin be done now what can I do to help him?
question: My cousing is a legal resident for 13 years married to an American Citizen with one daughter. His whole family lives legally in the US. He had a case for poss. 11350(A) then he got arrested for DUI 23152(A) and (B) on those two he was reinstated on probation- but he got sentenced to 365 county jail for violation of probation (I think) 594(A) PC FEL. He broke a car's window.
question_tags: DUI,DUI as a criminal offense,DUI arrest,DUI probation,DUI and immigration status,Immigration,Deportation,Immigration detention,Immigration court,Cancellation of removal in deportation,Immigrant status,Bankruptcy,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Felony crime,Crimes against society,Criminal charges for probation violation,Criminal arrest,Criminal court,Probation for criminal conviction,Deportation defense
answers:
It is not possible to give you a certain answer to your question without reviewing the criminal court dockets of ALL your cousin's criminal cases.

Your cousin needs an attorney who practices immigration law [and, especially deportation defense] and criminal law.

If a legal permanent resident like your cousin, who has such long residence, is sent to Immigration Court for removal proceedings, he is eligible for cancellation of removal, if he does not have a conviction which is an "aggravated felony" [which can be a misdemeanor] under immigration law.

For certain, your cousin needs to fight removal, and not agree to be deported, just so he can get out of custody. If he is removed, he loses his legal status, and may not be able to get it back in the future.

It's always best to retain an immigration lawyer BEFORE the person with a hold is picked up by ICE. The sooner, the better.

With 13 years as a permanent resident, it is possible that your cousin might qualify for cancellation of removal if none of his convictions are considered to be aggravated felonies. You need an immigration lawyer that is very experienced and knowledgeable with regard to immigration consequences of crimes. In Los Angeles, I would suggest you contact Stacy Tolchin of Van der Hout, Brigagliano and Nightingale, or Stuart Folinsky.
